speaker: Teacher
text: Tell me again what was "I want" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux." So if you want to say, "I want to reserve," in French, where do you start in order to find "to reserve"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. So how would you say "to reserve" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Quelque chose." Good. And these are two words in French. "Quelque chose." "Do you want something"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux quelque chose?" "Do you want to reserve something"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux réserver quelque chose?" So we see that we have a lot of French vocabulary, you know, that we can access through English and we won't realize just how much that vocabulary is until we just start trying to share our thoughts and ideas in French. Then we'll notice all of the words that we can convert over. Mostly, we'll just have to change a little the way we pronounce those words, but we can have a go and see the feedback and see how quickly we're understood and ask natives for the pronunciation, but we can always, you know, make that attempt and try to pull words out of our Latin English or our French English. And we also want to be constantly listening out for words we might recognize too, just that they will sound a little different in French. The more we do that, the more we'll train our ear and begin to notice many, many words in French that we recognize through English. "Thing" was "chose." And "something"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Quelque chose." "Recommendation" in French is slightly different. We get a slight change. We don't have "recommendation" but "recommandation." Like "to recommand" rather than "to recommend." "Recommandation." And again, the N on the end of "recommand" is half silent, you know? "Recommandation." So we build "to recommend" from "recommandation." So how would that be?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good, but also the first E is more like "je" in this case. "Recommander." So how would you say, "I want to recommend something"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux recommander quelque chose." "Do you want to recommend something"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux recommander quelque chose?" Very good. And if we lose this RE, the "re" at the beginning of "recommander," we will get "commander," which means "to order." "Commander." "To order."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux commander quelque chose." "Do you want to order something"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu veux commander quelque chose?" What was "I want" again?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux." Now, both of these "veux" are actually spelt V-E-U-X. We have an X on the end, but we don't hear this X because French doesn't tend to pronounce the consonants written on the ends of words. "I can" or "I am able" in French is "je peux."

speaker: Teacher
text: And this "peux" is spelt P-E-U-X. We have that X, that silent X on the end there. What was "a little"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Un peu." So the "pe" of "je peux," "I can," and the "pe" of "un peu" sounds exactly the same. With "un peu," we have P-E-U, but then with "je peux," "I can," we have P-E-U-X, but we don't pronounce that X. How would you say "you can"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu peux." "You can celebrate a little." "You can celebrate a little."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu peux célébrer un peu." So "tu peux" and "un peu" sound the same, but the "pe" of "can," of "able," "able to," is actually related to the word "power" and "possibility." The "pe" of "power" and "possibility" shares a root with this "pe." What you can, what you are able to do, is your possibility, your power, no? So that's where we get "je peux" from P-E-U-X. And again, we have the silent X on the end, just like in "je veux," "I want." How would you say "I can, I am able to reserve something"?

speaker: Student
text: "Je peux reser-" "Je peux réserver quelque chose."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je peux réserver quelque chose." What was "to recommend" or "to recommand" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Recommander." So the E of the RE there at the beginning sounds like the E of "je" in this case. "Recommander." And also we have a slight change in "recommend," which is "recommand" in French. "Recommander." "I can recommend something."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je peux recommander quelque chose." "You can." What was "you can" again?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu peux recommander quelque chose?" "Can you order"? "Can you command"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu peux commander." So we said if we get rid of this RE from "recommander," and we're left with "commander," and this means "to order," you know, like in a restaurant, for example.
